item.title: Amiberry-Lite on Raspberry Pi
item.description:
Amiberry by Dimitris Panokostas is the best emulator for the Amiga home computer. It is designed to run on various platforms, including Raspberry Pi, Linux, and Windows. It provides a user-friendly interface and supports a wide range of Amiga games and applications. Amiberry aims to deliver an authentic Amiga experience by accurately emulating the hardware and software of the original system. It includes features such as support for WHDLoad games, customizable controls, and various display options.

Homepage: https://amiberry.com
GitHub: https://github.com/BlitterStudio/amiberry
Wiki: https://github.com/BlitterStudio/amiberry/wiki

I’m going to show you how to install Amiberry-Lite on a Raspberry Pi 400 running the official Raspberry Pi OS. This guide assumes you have a basic understanding of using the command line and have a Raspberry Pi set up with an internet connection. If you don’t have the official Raspberry Pi OS installed, you can download it from the Raspberry Pi website. Most of the times I use an old external SSD drive for better performance and durability. I’m using the lite version of Amiberry because it is better for emulating Amiga games on Pi 4 (you can find the details on the official wiki page).

Installation üíæ

Download the latest release of Amiberry-Lite from the GitHub releases page. Look for the file named amiberry-lite-<version>-debian-<distro>-<arch>.zip. If you don’t know which version to download, you can check which distro you are using by running the following command in the terminal:

lsb_release -a

This will display information about your Linux distribution, including the version and codename. Make sure to download the correct version of Amiberry-Lite for your system architecture (e.g., armhf for Raspberry Pi 2/3, arm64 for Pi 4/400).

To check the architecture of your Raspberry Pi, you can run the following command:

arch

In my case the result is aarch64, which means I need to download the arm64 version of Amiberry-Lite.

Unzip the downloaded file to a directory of your choice. You can use the following commands in the terminal to unzip and install :

cd ~/Downloads 
unzip amiberry-lite-v5.8.8-debian-bookworm-arm64.zip
sudo apt install ./amiberry-lite_5.8.8_arm64.deb

This will install Amiberry-Lite and its dependencies on your Raspberry. You can now run it by typing amiberry-lite in the terminal.

Running üëæ

Get your Amiga Floppy Disk (ADF) images ready and prepare to enter nostalgia mode. I’m going to run Battle Squadron, which is one of my favorites Amiga classics, you can download it at the official game site. Select the “Floppy Drives” screen and load the ADF file in DF0:, you can adjust the Floppy Drive Emulation Speed slider to 800% for faster loading times. While running the emulator press F12 (Fn-F2 on Pi 400) to open the Amiberry GUI. Standard Joysticks worked out of the box.

Have fun remembering the good old days of Amiga gaming!

/thanks MiDWan! üëç
